citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The vaccines for the dogs are not being stored at the proper temperature. The temperature inside the refrigerator
containing the vaccines is 58 degrees F according to the inspector's Kestrel. The label on the vaccines state they are to
be stored between 35-46 degrees F. Storing vaccines at an inappropriate temperature may interfere with their ability to
be effective which could leave dogs without proper protection against serious and deadly diseases.
Each dealer must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee
must store the vaccines at the appropriate temperature and ensure that all other medical products are properly stored at
all times in order to support the health of the dogs.
To be corrected by: From this day forward

The Program of Veterinary Care is incomplete and the schedule for the physical examination of the dogs by the attending
veterinarian is missing. Records indicate that the attending veterinarian conducted a visual examination of the adult dogs
on June 02, 2022, but no records indicate that a physical examination has been performed. The licensee stated that the
puppies are each physically examined before they are sold, but this plan is not documented.
Failure to document the frequency of physical examinations may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if
the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care. Failure to have the dogs physically examined by the attending
veterinarian at least once every 12 months may allow medical concerns to go unnoticed and the conditions could worsen.
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that is developed, documented in writing, and signed
by the attending veterinarian and includes a complete physical examination from head to tail of each dog by the attending
veterinarian not less than once every 12 months. The licensee must add the schedule for the physical examinations of
the adult dogs and puppies to the program of veterinary care and ensure that each dog receives the physical examination
in order to support their health and well-being.
To be corrected by: The schedule of examinations must be documented by 14-March-2023. All dogs must receive the
physical examination not less than once every 12 months from this day forward.

The Program of Veterinary Care is incomplete and the preventative care and treatment plans to ensure healthy and
unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth is missing. Failure to
document the preventative care and treatment plans may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the
animals are receiving adequate veterinary care.
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that is developed, documented in writing, and signed
by the attending veterinarian and includes the preventative care and treatment plans to ensure healthy and unmatted hair
coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. The licensee must add these missing
plans to the Program of Veterinary Care to ensure the dogs are receiving adequate veterinary care.
To be corrected by: 14-March-2023

The licensee had approximately a quarter of the kennel population tested for heartworm and intestinal parasites (fecals) in
May or June of 2022. The identification of which dogs were tested is not documented in writing on a medical record.
Failure to document the animal identification can interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine which medical
record belongs to which animal and if adequate veterinary care is being provided.
Each dealer shall keep copies of medical records that includes the identity of the animal, including identifying marks,
tattoos, or tags on the animal and the animal’s breed, sex, and age. The licensee must ensure that all medical records
contain the animal's identification along with all other required information.
To be corrected by: From this day forward

The licensee had approximately a quarter of the kennel population tested for heartworm and intestinal parasites (fecals) in
May or June of 2022. The results of the tests are not documented in writing on a medical record. Failure to document the
results of the testing may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the dogs are receiving adequate
veterinary care.
Each dealer shall keep copies of medical records that include the results of all screening, routine, or other required or
recommended tests or examinations. The licensee must document the results of all heartworm and fecal testing and
ensure that all medical records are complete and contain all the required information.
To be corrected by: From this day forward
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
End Section

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The vaccines for the dogs are not being stored at the proper temperature.  The temperature inside the refrigerator 
containing the vaccines is 58 degrees F according to the inspector's Kestrel.  The label on the vaccines state they are to 
be stored between 35-46 degrees F.  Storing vaccines at an inappropriate temperature may interfere with their ability to 
be effective which could leave dogs without proper protection against serious and deadly diseases. 
 
Each dealer must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases and injuries.  The licensee 
must store the vaccines at the appropriate temperature and ensure that all other medical products are properly stored at 
all times in order to support the health of the dogs. 
 
To be corrected by:  From this day forward 
3.13(a)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The Program of Veterinary Care is incomplete and the schedule for the physical examination of the dogs by the attending 
veterinarian is missing.  Records indicate that the attending veterinarian conducted a visual examination of the adult dogs 
on June 02, 2022, but no records indicate that a physical examination has been performed.  The licensee stated that the

puppies are each physically examined before they are sold, but this plan is not documented.   
 
Failure to document the frequency of physical examinations may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if 
the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care.  Failure to have the dogs physically examined by the attending 
veterinarian at least once every 12 months may allow medical concerns to go unnoticed and the conditions could worsen.   
 
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that is developed, documented in writing, and signed 
by the attending veterinarian and includes a complete physical examination from head to tail of each dog by the attending 
veterinarian not less than once every 12 months.  The licensee must add the schedule for the physical examinations of 
the adult dogs and puppies to the program of veterinary care and ensure that each dog receives the physical examination 
in order to support their health and well-being. 
 
To be corrected by:  The schedule of examinations must be documented by 14-March-2023.  All dogs must receive the 
physical examination not less than once every 12 months from this day forward. 
3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The Program of Veterinary Care is incomplete and the preventative care and treatment plans to ensure healthy and 
unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth is missing.  Failure to 
document the preventative care and treatment plans may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the 
animals are receiving adequate veterinary care. 
 
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that is developed, documented in writing, and signed

by the attending veterinarian and includes the preventative care and treatment plans to ensure healthy and unmatted hair 
coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth.  The licensee must add these missing 
plans to the Program of Veterinary Care to ensure the dogs are receiving adequate veterinary care. 
 
To be corrected by:  14-March-2023 
3.13(b)(1) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee had approximately a quarter of the kennel population tested for heartworm and intestinal parasites (fecals) in 
May or June of 2022.  The identification of which dogs were tested is not documented in writing on a medical record.  
Failure to document the animal identification can interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine which medical 
record belongs to which animal and if adequate veterinary care is being provided. 
 
Each dealer shall keep copies of medical records that includes the identity of the animal, including identifying marks, 
tattoos, or tags on the animal and the animal’s breed, sex, and age.  The licensee must ensure that all medical records 
contain the animal's identification along with all other required information.   
 
To be corrected by:  From this day forward 
3.13(b)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee had approximately a quarter of the kennel population tested for heartworm and intestinal parasites (fecals) in 
May or June of 2022.  The results of the tests are not documented in writing on a medical record.  Failure to document the 
results of the testing may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the dogs are receiving adequate

veterinary care. 
 
Each dealer shall keep copies of medical records that include the results of all screening, routine, or other required or 
recommended tests or examinations.  The licensee must document the results of all heartworm and fecal testing and 
ensure that all medical records are complete and contain all the required information. 
 
To be corrected by:  From this day forward 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative. 
 
End Section
